Topic.Title: If consoles are dead, why is google developing an android console. LOL.

Message.Msg: It's a legitimate question that you asked, so I shall accord you with a serious answer. Google's console, if materilized, will be part of EL Goog's ecosystem. This console arguably would not be standing alone, like PS4 or Nintendo Wii U or the likes; rather it will be communicable with other Android devices - phones, tablets and laptops. Apple;s rumored console is reportedly part of the AppleTV also. xBox family of consoles are somewhat in between as MS is far from a media giant, but I think this may be one of its strategic goals. From this perspective the Xbox One is in a stronger position than PS4. Still don't get it? - go find someone who will dumb it down for you. (Suggestion: one of the SA bloggers)

Message.Title: BBRY takes a bath - Shares off 25%
Message.Msg: Blackberry offered few signs of a long-promised turnaround on Friday, with an unexpected quarterly operating loss, few details on sales of its make-or-break new devices and no return to profit in the current quarter. BlackBerry, struggling to compete against Apple Inc's iPhone, Samsung's Galaxy smartphones and other devices powered by Google's Android operating system, reported a net loss of $84 million, or 16 cents a share, in the first quarter ended June 1.

Topic.Title: WSJ just in: Google is developing Android video game console

Message.Msg: As I said before, the long-term winners will be decided on, besides performance factors, who owns the most popularized ecosystem(s) and which players are feeding into it - ie. Google and NVIDIA would be a safe guess. There is more from the above referenced WSJ article: ""Google's head of Android, Sundar Pichai, in May said more than 900 million devices powered by Android had been activated worldwide, up from 400 million a year ago and 100 million two years ago. Jen-Hsun Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia Corp., NVDA +0.43% which makes microchips for devices powered by Android, said in a recent interview that over time there would be three billion people who use Android devices, and that one million programmers globally are already using the software to build applications or devices. He said Android is poised to disrupt the videogame and consumer-electronics industry; computer systems in cars; as well as personal computing, such as desktop computers. He declined to discuss any unreleased products. Think about it....

Message.Title: NVIDIA Tesla GPU Accelerators Power World's Most Energy Efficient Supercomputer
Message.Msg: Latest Green500 Results Establish GPU Accelerator Advantage vs. CPUs, All Other Accelerators for Energy Efficient, High Performance Supercomputing SANTA CLARA, CA -- (Marketwired) -- 06/28/13 -- NVIDIA today announced that NVIDIA® Tesla® GPU accelerators are powering the world's two most energy efficient supercomputers, based on the latest Green500 list published today. The winning system is 'Eurora' at CINECA, Italy's largest supercomputing center, in Casalecchio di Reno. Equipped with NVIDIA Kepler™ architecture-based GPU accelerators -- the highest-performance, most efficient accelerators ever built -- Eurora delivers 3,210 MFlops per watt, making it 2.6 times more energy efficient than the best system using Intel CPUs alone (at Météo France). It also greatly surpasses the most efficient Intel Xeon Phi accelerator-based system, 'Beacon,' at the National Institute for Computational Sciences, at the University of Tennessee. The number-two system on the June 2013 Green500 list is the 'Aurora Tigon' supercomputer at the Selex ES facilities Chieti, Italy. These top two systems are powered by advanced Eurotech high-performance 'Aurora' servers, equipped with NVIDIA Tesla K20 GPU accelerators. More broadly, NVIDIA Kepler GPU accelerator-based systems in the top 100 spots on the Green500 list are 50 percent more energy efficient on average than the latest Intel Xeon Phi-based systems.

Message.Title: Breaking: Intel technology chief Rattner to step down.....
Message.Msg: SOURCE: WSJ One of the most familiar faces at Intel events, Justin Rattner, is giving up the post of chief technology officer at the giant chip maker. Intel said Thursday that Rattner, 65 years old, is hitting the company’s mandatory retirement age for corporate officers. He will depart immediately to attend to what the company called a “pressing family matter,” but will subsequently return to Intel in a post still to be determined, the company said. Rattner also is a vice president and director of Intel Labs, the company’s research arm. Those operations will report to Renee James, Intel’s newly appointed president, until further leadership decisions are made, Intel said. The announcement comes as something of a surprise, as Rattner hosted an Intel research event in San Francisco Tuesday with no mention of any impending changes. Rattner, like James, spent most of his time at Intel’s large operations in Oregon rather than at the corporate headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif. He joined the company in 1973. Unlike many senior technologists at the company, he did not start out in fields such as designing semiconductors or perfecting recipes for how to manufacture them. Rather, Rattner is best known for his expertise in the field of high-performance computing. In the 1980s and 1990s, he helped advance the concepts of “massively parallel” computers, built using hundreds or thousands of standard microprocessor chips rather than a few custom-built calculating engines. Intel at one time sold such systems itself, though later withdrew to focus on supplying chips for them. Rattner was known for his work on a machine called ASCII Red that was built by Intel and installed at Sandia National Laboratories in 1996. The massive machine was credited as the first computer to sustain one trillion scientific calculations per second....

Topic.Title: If consoles are dead, why is google developing an android console. LOL.

Message.Msg: "Let me explain to you, why consoles are not dead. REAL GAMERS need a 50" screen to play REAL GAMES, not your piddly Angry birds toy games" That's exactly why Google and Nvidia are making these devices; they want to encourage higher quality third party game development. Unfortunately bringing in gamers is somewhat of a catch 22. Gamers want high quality third party game development; the high quality third party game developers want gamers. Someone has to start somewhere, and Nvidia, Google, and Apple clearly want to get the ball rolling.

Topic.Title: Nvidia's story doesn't add up. You can't fix more than a few thousand units in one month.

Message.Msg: Dismantle, repair and repackage would depend entirely on the assembly stage of the defect, and I would probably say the thumbsticks are somewhere towards the end, so that is possible. If Nvidia has known of the issue for some time, they most likely have already developed plan B repair line; the fact that they announced the delay last week probably means that they line wasn't running as fast enough to meet the release date. As for the re-test aspect, have you ever worked in industry? Very rarely is every single product tested; what they will do however is a capability study with a random sampling of the repair line to determine if Shield is meeting the requirements.
